conclusion: The relationship between the volume V of an ideal gas of a certain mass and the thermodynamic temperature T is shown in the figure, the pressure of the gas in state A is pA=p0, the temperature TA= T0, the line segment AB is parallel to the V axis, and the extension line of BC is over the origin.

Recall the ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
Where P is pressure, V is volume, n is the number of moles (constant for the same mass), R is the gas constant, T is absolute temperature.
At state B: p₍B₎(2V₀) = nRT₀ (since T is constant along AB)
Since the right sides of both equations are equal: p₍B₎(2V₀) = p₀V₀

conclusion: According to the ideal gas law, the pressure must have halved.
